steps.text: Hello! Today we're exploring sets and mappings - fundamental concepts in mathematics. A set is a collection of distinct objects, and a mapping (or function) defines a relationship between sets.
steps.explanation: This notation means 'f is a mapping from set X to set Y'. For each element x in X, the mapping f assigns exactly one element y in Y.

steps.text: Let's look at a simple example of a set. A set can be defined by listing its elements inside curly braces.
steps.explanation: Set A contains the numbers 1 through 5. Sets have no specific order and don't contain duplicates. So {1,2,3} is the same set as {3,1,2}.

steps.text: Now let's define a simple mapping. We'll create a function from set A to the set of even numbers.
steps.explanation: This function takes each number from set A and multiplies it by 2, resulting in the even numbers {2,4,6,8,10}.

steps.text: An important property of mappings is whether they're injective (one-to-one). A mapping is injective if different inputs always produce different outputs.
steps.formula: f \text{ is injective} \iff f(x_1) = f(x_2) \Rightarrow x_1 = x_2
steps.explanation: Our function f(x) = 2x is injective because if f(x₁) = f(x₂), then 2x₁ = 2x₂, which means x₁ = x₂.

steps.text: Another important property is surjectivity (onto). A mapping is surjective if every element in the target set is reached by the mapping.
steps.formula: f \text{ is surjective} \iff \forall y \in Y, \exists x \in X: f(x) = y
steps.explanation: If we define our mapping as f: A → {2,4,6,8,10}, then f is surjective because every element in the target set is reached.
